title: Hungry Horse Test 1 (Live Low Stakes Test)
description: Based off of '99% of Players FAIL This Poker IQ Test' video by hungry horse poker

scenario.description: A weak player in the cut off open raises. The two players behind are strong players.

solution.hint: The players behind you are strong. The player before you is weak. Do you see any options that would allow you to play more often against the weaker player and avoid action with stronger players?
solution.explanation: With two regs behind, we should 3-bet raise to isolate the pot with the fish when we have position.

scenario.description: Passive player who is limping often raises.

solution.hint: By limping many of the hands they should be raising with, this leaves their raising range to be even stronger.
solution.explanation: Considering that the player is limping more often than they should, we should expect their raising range to be pretty strong. Therefore, we want to fold since 9h8h is not strong enough to compete with their range.

solution.hint: Your hand has the potential to make a big hand(straights and flushes), but is probably losing to most of your opponents' calling range.
solution.explanation: Considering the stack depth, calling is appropriate at this price. If the flop is favorable, we can continue, otherwise we can quickly fold.

scenario.description: Reg in the LJ raises. All the players behind are fish.

solution.hint: With so many weak players behind, we want them to join in. Our hand is not at the top of our range.
solution.explanation: With many weak players behind, we want to call to keep those plaers in considering our hand is not strong enough to 3-bet raise against the strong reg.

scenario.description: We have a reg in the CO and fish on the BTN.

solution.hint: Pair of 9s is a pretty strong hand against most hands, only beat by higher ranked pairs.
solution.explanation: 3-bet raise to put pressure on the pot money. 9s is strong enough to compete against most of the opponents' range.

solution.hint: AQ suited is a solid holding that can compete against many hands.
solution.explanation: 3-betting a player who is capable of 3-betting allows you to capitalize on their weaker hands with a strong AQ suited holding. If the villain continues their agression, approach with caution.

solution.hint: Since the opponent is out of position, they are less likely to call a 4-bet unless they are at the top of their range.
solution.explanation: With JJ, calling is best as we want to avoid running into tough situations by 4-betting. JJs is certainly strong enough to call, so we do not want to fold this hand yet.

solution.hint: We have many hands beat. How can we get weak hands to continue, and strong hands to signal to us their strength?
solution.explanation: By choosing the smaller bet size, we get value from the strong and weak parts of our opponents range. With a really strong hand, the opponents may reraise and signal their strength. With pairs, straight draws, or even Ace high, the opponent may be enticed to continue for a small bet.

scenario.description: Opponent calls our raise preflop and we find ourselves with a set out of position on the flop.

solution.hint: Since the opponent is in position, they are more likely to bet even with weaker hands to take advantage of their positioning. This means we can be less worried about getting money in on the flop.
solution.explanation: Players in position will tend to bet with their advantageous position, allowing us to check to see where they are with their hand and to hide the strength of our own hand.

scenario.description: Flop comes and you check. Opponent now bets 40.

solution.hint: With our very strong hand, we want to play for stacks by the river if the opponent happens to have a strong hand that they will not be willing to fold(which their large bet suggests).
solution.explanation: With the opponent's large bet, it seems they like their hand. We want to put in a lot of money to punish all of their very strong hands like two pairs, straight+flush draws, and AQ.

solution.hint: We have a strong hand, so we want more money in the middle. Is it likely for our opponent on the button to bet on a 4 way street? How would our opponents respond to a large bet if they are strong vs if they are weak?
solution.explanation: Betting a small-medium amount allows us to keep our opponents with weaker hands in for one more street, while also giving the chance for strong hands to raise.

scenario.description: Flop comes and villain checks to us.

solution.hint: The board is dry and static, which means there isn't much potential for our opponent's hand to improve and only few hands in the range connect well to the flop. In this position, with our very strong hand, we want to target strong hands like Ax since other hands are not likely to continue.
solution.explanation: On this dry static board, our opponent's weak hands are unlikely to continue to any bet. By betting large, we can force Ax into a tough spot and get more money in against those combinations.

scenario.description: Flop comes. Notice that our opponent is short stacked on the button with 380 chips.

solution.hint: We have a strong hand, and our opponents are unlikely to stab on this dry, static board. We want to get in all of their short stack by the river.
solution.explanation: With this static, dry board our opponent is less likely to stab. We can start betting now and easily get all of our opponents money in.
